needle: Figs are one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.

model_response.text:
Most people think that philosophy is about exploring the nature of reality.  But that's not right.[8] <PAUSE> Philosophy is actually about avoiding confusion.  You can be
confused by almost anything, but it seems most likely to happen
if you're trying to deal with abstractions.[9] <PAUSE> This is the central fact of philosophy.  And the problem is that you
really can't work with abstractions.  The first time I tried to use
abstraction, I was in a conversation with a group of economists
about why the United States isn't rich.  I thought to myself that
they could probably agree on the point (who knows, maybe no one in
the room disagreed), and so I tried to get beyond the trivial
question of what to do with it.  Instead, the conversation
dissolved into a maelstrom of detail.  I was no longer talking
about poverty; I was discussing what kind of policies would produce
an economy that has no poverty, or how to measure it, or whether
there really is such an economy, or what would happen if there
is, and what we might expect of it, or what people expect of it, or
what we should expect of it (and whether that's the right thing to
expect), and what we might expect of the people who live in it,
and how they might expect it (and whether they should expect it),
and what we should expect of them (and whether that's the right
thing to expect), and what we might expect of the people who
make up the society (and whether they should expect it), and what
we should expect of them (and whether that's the right thing to
expect), and whether we should expect people to expect it, and
whether they should expect the others to expect them to expect
it, and what it would mean for us to expect such things to be
expected, and so forth and so on, and what would be a good thing
for them to expect to be expected to expect, and whether it's
worth it, and how long before they stop expecting anything to
be expected to be expected of them, and so forth.[10] <PAUSE>  In the end, it was hard to see why there even is an
economy or what it should be.  It wasn't that the conversation had
ended: it
